reviewText:
A lovely little twin stick shooter that will make your eyes very happy!
Frantic, colourful, cheap and most importantly, FUN!

Does not take itself too seriously but there is a seriously solid game under the neon and terribly nice compliments the game flashes at you.
Quite possibly the politest game I've played and I've played High Tea simulator 2007!

The levels are bite sized but don't let that put you off.
This is designed to be taken in small bites.
Small small psychoreactive bites!

Don't let the play time fool you.
I've played the previous versions of this and played it through beta.

This version has just made a very shiny thing a lot more shiny!

reviewText:
Death Ray Manta has lasers in his head
He blew up his house, now he lives in space instead.

Then at the local post office that same day but later
He explained he'd soon be moving as his bungalow was now a crater.

They were very helpful and gave him a change of address form
As though laser house explosions were really the daily norm.

But the constable called and was grumpy and told him if he left town there'd be trouble
As his fat black handlebarred bicycle was now under three tons of rubble.

So in dead of night to deafening synth and psychadelic fury
Death Ray Manta highjacked a roman candle and made for Alpha Centauri.

...

Death Ray Manta SE is the most satisfying shooter I've played in years, *maybe ever*. Perhaps if I was a huge shooter or retro arcade fan that would mean more, but I'd certainly favour it to Geometry Wars or Hotline Miami - both fine games, but DRMSE just feels better for me.

It certainly starts as it intends to continue: even the title screen is hyper saturated neon with a deliberate effort to make figuring out what the hell you should do to start the game far more unclear than the norm.

I hated it first time I played it. But I get it now, this is genius.

Because it isn't the title screen. It's more like the You died
recommended: left click to retry" screen. Like Super Meat Boy players failing and rapidly retrying is the norm
voteText:
so stopping the neon and synth would be senseless.
And making it less a shock to the eyes and ears would ironically make it far more jarring once the first level starts again.

Nothing out of the game feels out of place
helpfulPercent:
oddly everything feels simultaneously hard to accept and like it dovetails together perfectly.

It throws too much neon and synth at you; once you overcome that adversity and you feel unstoppable; not many games feel this great continually to play. It's perhaps almost an equivalent of getting over the shock of trying tabasco sauce for the first time and later discovering a lifelong love of spicy food.

Death Ray Manta SE is something special

reviewText: A quick-n-trippy little dual-stick shooter in the vein of Robotron, Llamatron and probably a horde of other games that end with -tron"
date: Death Ray Manta is carefully designed and balanced with all the skill and care you'd expect from a developer that's dedicated a frankly worrying percentage of their life to games about sea-life shooting things up with lasers.\n\nDeath is almost as fast as restarting. The graphics are loud and neon
recommended: but in a way where you never lose track of what and where everything is. Score-increasing gems vanish quickly
hoursPlayed: and are always placed as to encourage reckless manoeuvres. Everything is built to encourage fast play and a just-one-more-go attitude.\n\nAnd of course
voteText: there are humorous little touches - enemies exploding into words of encouragement
helpfulPercent: the gloriously synthy soundtrack - that keep things light-hearted even as you get to grips with things. It's a reflex-heavy high-score rush with a friendly face
votesHelpful: always there for when you have five minutes or so to kill while waiting for your Important Business E-Mails.\n\nIf you're a fan of Robotron

reviewText:
Very cool little game!

It has a great vibe, although it wasn't very well communicated, from the start.

Death Ray Manta is a very hippie shoot 'em up game. There are no leaderboards and no achievements, meaning you can only compete with yourself! There's also a score cap, which may or may not be your own objective during your time.

The game has 32 levels, each with a special collectible that adds a point to your score. The levels get progressively harder and more complex, introducing several subtly different enemies to keep things interesting.
I found it really tough! Even thought each levels lasts only for a few seconds, I took 6+ hours to beat it! Everything dies in one hit, but so do you. You can also shoot the enemies' bullets, destroying them.

The game is fair, for the most part. I will agree that it can be really frustrating, though! Especially near the end, where I was trying to maximize my score, and got killed after a near perfect attempt... still, it felt really rewarding whenever I beat a new personal record.


The only problem I have with it is how the visuals are very aggressive, at first. The game isn't very clear about its objective either, which, combined with all the flashing colors, will make the first few rounds very very short and disorientating. It almost stopped me from playing.
... Deciding to give it a go regardless, I certainly don't regret it!

It's a very small, but focused game with a single purpose, that it does really well! I'd also like to add that it feels great to play with a controller. It's very fluid and certainly has good feedback with the controller's rumble.

If you're looking for a quick shmup, give it a go.

reviewText:
Death Ray Manta is a pure twin-stick arena shooter arcade game.
You jump right into the vibrant colored action and tackle your highscore.

Pro:
+ pure, condensed action
+ smooth controls
+ great BGM
+ solid SFX
+ vibrant colors fill your screen
+ easy to understand
+ no DRM
+ cheap
+ trading cards

Con:
- highscore doesn't show other players
- no achievements, yet
- no menu, yet

Neutral:
0 transition between stages is sometimes unclear (it doesn't interrupt the game)
0 text gets repetitive
0 enemy variety could be higher (it is sufficient)

reviewText:
This is a real treat if you enjoyed coin-op games in their glory days - hand me over my walking cane, will you?
It looks like a simple twin-stick shooter game with rooms taking seconds to clear, but it actually features a very simple score mechanic that requires you to learn and remember the level layouts.
It is as much if not more memory than reflex-based.
You got a single life, so you will learn!
The sights and sounds, in all their paroxystic approach, are very fitting the silly theme of the game, and true(?) to its name, DRM can be run freely outside of Steam.

I have been loving this game since its first iteration, and my highscore is pathetic so I won't share it with you.

For the anecdote and developper stories lovers: I ran into an issue the other day - my new keyboard layout wouldn't allow me to play the game properly. The author, Mr. Fearon, replied to me within the day and pushed an update allowing key configuration. I could enjoy his game again within 48 hours.

reviewText:
A rather hard one to judge, as I seldomly play twin stick shooters, but this one isn't great at that either.
The good thing here is that it offers everything it promises: very colorfull laser fights in space and some old sci-fi/disco theme.
The bad thing is that that is ALL that is offered: it's a single track, sound effects are repeated the whole time and after a few variations of the enemies...that's pretty much it. No replays, power-ups, lives, ammo, weapons or anything. The only progression is in the levels, and these just add more mindless monsters each time.

Of course for four bucks I don't really expect much more than that. And it certainly has that okay
date: I'm dead...let's play again!!!" feel that old arcade games had. Controls aren't bad (note: controls are a must. It's not even half as fun with keyboard and mouse). But aside from the audio that gets repetitive fast
recommended: there is quite a lot of visual cluttering. Navigating between monsters is hard enough as it is but it throws pretty fireworks at you as well.\n\nSo...I wouldn't recommend. But wouldn't stop you from getting it either (unless perhaps you don't have a gamepad controller with 2 sticks on it)."

reviewText:
Colorful, crazy, cool.

This game is so simple in concept and executed flawlessly. Guide your fishy thing through each of the stages, rushing to the short-lived gem and taking down the wave of baddies. The stages are short and played at a breakneck pace - the action never lets up! The gem being on a timer forces you into risky situations - a great balance of risk and reward.

This game is tough - you'll die a *lot* - but it's very fair. You know you were at fault every time, finding yourself praising the designer for how expertly crafted each of the stages are. This game nails the oh
date: just one more go" thing perfectly; you die and press fire to be back in the action within a second.\n\nThe graphics are crazy and colorful. At first I felt overwhelmed by what was going on
recommended: but you soon get to recognize what is what. The music is great and you actually get to hear more of the track as you last longer; it's like a nice little treat for staying alive.\n\nWorth every cent. Go buy it!"

reviewText:
Death Ray Manta is about controlling space and space controlling you. In space.

Death Ray Manta is about getting high on your own supply of icthycranial laserbeams.

Death Ray Manta is about moving your butt and biding your time. Death Ray Manta wants you to go fast. Death Ray Manta wants you to go slow. The lesson is: Death Ray Manta wants you.

Death Ray Manta is about being tough but fair. Death Ray Manta is not a cynical jerk like those other games. Death Ray Manta loves you.

Death Ray Manta is about succeeding on your own terms. Because you're beautiful! Yes, even you, ugly.

Death Ray Manta is about the prettiest darn game you ever will see. The lights will flash. The grins will form.

Death Ray Manta is a masterpiece. It is the culmination of an auteur working at the height of his abilities. You will play the game. The game will play you. What more could you ask for?

reviewText:
A non-biased quick look @ the game:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lk-mBS0TTyw

Reminds me of the glory days of Robotron but with a cool modern twist, and it's a blast.  Two sticks, one fish, some flashing lights. Death Ray Manta is, quite definitely, a videogame in the purest sense. Rejigged, rebuilt, remastered for Steam in the year of our Molyneux 2015.

Death Ray Manta is a short form top down arena shooter where you blow up enemies using colourful laserbeams. You spawn in the centre of the screen, moments later the screen is filled with mines, robots, rabbits and lasers from beyond the stars. Collect space gems for a bonus and shoot everything else that you can in order to flash lights at yourself. Aim for your own personal high score. How far into fish space can you get?

32 screens of increasingly colourful and crazy laser firing mayhem from the brains behind (amongst other things) Squid Yes, Not So Octopus, SYNSO 2 and the challenge mode in Waves. Also, he's that hairy dude off the internet. You know the one.

Death Ray Manta is made with the fine assistance of Mike Daw who provided the legwarmer chic tunes and Andy White, who helped out under the hood and kept me sane. Cover art by the legendary Ste Pickford. - Recommended!

reviewText: Death Ray Manta is a game wherein you steer a techno-manta through a series of increasingly difficult techno-arenas, firing rainbows at brightly colored enemies and collecting short-lived gems".   Enemies explode in words of encouragement when they are shot; an uplifting 80's synth music pulses in the background; prompts flash things like "You're brilliant!" and "Strong Fish!  Beautiful Fish!"  in the brief moments between levels.\n\nThe whole thing is reminiscent of a PSX-era shooter like Nitrous Oxide:  Bright
hoursPlayed: and innocently weird.\n\nThere are two ways to score a point:  By beating a level
voteText: or by collecting aforementioned gems.  The former is obligatory (by defeating all of your opponents) but you only have a few moments to accomplish the latter before they vanish.  The time-sensitivity of gem collecting puts a twist on the gameplay
helpfulPercent: since you can't just sit around and play defensively
votesHelpful: but if you rush to collect a gem before it disappears
votesTotal: you'll expose yourself to colliding with enemies and projectiles--something that is relatively easy to do while navigating the neon chaos of colors and shapes in this game.\n\nThe game may not immediately grab you.  It's incredibly simple--a twin-stick shooter reduced to a few of its most elementary components
votesFunny: which are then thrown at you in the tiniest of bites--but there's a certain allure in its simplicity.  It's a game that can be played for thirty seconds or thirty minutes
commentsCount: with a deceptive difficulty that can stir up a  "one more try" urge every time you fail."

reviewText:
Death Ray Manta presents a visual masterpiece combined with quick, twin-stick arcade gameplay.  While the visuals can be really overwhelming at first, once you get used to them you can appreciate both the graphical design of the game and the actual gameplay.  The mechanics aren’t complicated, yet each level you complete gives you a sense of achievement.  You do have to restart every time you die, yet this makes the game even more addicting as it presents a true challenge.

Bonus:  It works well with mouse and keyboard.  You don't need a controller to play this game successfully.

reviewText:
I'm going to leave my origional review below just for posterity.

First of all I would like to thank the developer for taking the time to respond to my review, and for taking the time to look into one of my origional gripes with the game, which was the game wouldn't quit when I hit escape, it would just start again. I have reinstalled the game since my scathing review on 9/18, and I'm happy to say that bug is now fixed.

Futhermore, the developer has added an actual menu, so you arn't immediatly thrown into the game. After playing it again with an open mind, I'm happy to say the game is in a much more playable state, and I found myself having quite a bit of fun with it. At this point I would like to formally retract my vote of not recommending this game, and offically say its worth getting.

For those looking for a current review, the game is basically like Tempest 3000 had a child with Asteroids. The controls are done with wasd and the mouse is used for aiming, which gives you more control then the old school keyboard shooters. The graphics are still a bit too flashy for my tastes, but at least at this point they arn't bothering me as much as before. Overall this is a pretty decent top down shooter.

--------------------------------ORIGONAL REVIEW-----------------------------

This game is a mess. First of all, when you start the game, it waits about 3 seconds and then puts you into the action, no instructions, just blaring music and seizure inducing colors.

When you start to play the game, its awful from purely a gameplay perspective. The controls are simple, move the ship with your wasd keys and aim and shoot with the mouse cursor. The issue lies in the games flashy graphics, obviously inspired by tempest 3000. With so much flashing backgrounds, particle effects, and psychedelic colors, its very difficult to discern whats an enemy and whats part of the background. Not only does that cause eye strain, but that leads you to some very cheap and frustrating deaths.

The final nail in the coffin comes when you want to stop playing this mess. You hit escape, press the quit key...and are brought back to the menu, where the game starts seconds later. The only way I've found to actually quit this game is to alt tab out and force quit. I know this is an indy game but that is not acceptable even for an alpha release.

In short, I'm sad to report this game just fails on every level.

reviewText:
If you have sensitivity to lights and flashing colors, avoid this game. I have a mild sensitivity, but the effects are so OTT that I couldn't see what was happening most of the time, and my eyeballs started aching quickly.

When you first start, you are thrown into the game without any hint at what you should do, and it pressed every button trying to find options for gameplay. It was after a few deaths that I realised it is a duel stick controller game, and the right stick is used for shooting! Once I got that, I managed a few levels, and there was fun to be had... until the effects made me head start pounding and my eyes feel like they are bleeding.

I won't be playing anymore, but if you have no issues with light sensitivity or strobe like effects, you might have fun with this game, for a little while at least.

The gameplay mostly consists of shooting lasers at strange alien creatures while you move around an enclosed area. Of course, that's only ten percent of the game, most of the other chunk of the game being the bit that will give you an epileptic seizure, just a heads up. Decent game, ignore my play time. 7/10

reviewText:
This game is so amazing.

It's cheap
It's fun
It's colorful
It's fast
It even gives you praise while playing!
This game is clearly silly in a strange way, but gameplay-wise it holds strong. The controls are tight, and you won't die for anything you don't deserve to. It isn't easy to get in and play at first, but once you've given it a few shots you'll get the hang of it. Also it's a good way to practice this type of game, since you can play so many games in such a short time.
The colors are beautiful, and even though it looks like it should be it's not that graphics intensive.

I'd give it a solid 9/10. A few things could easily put it up to a 10 in my books (but I'm an amateur so I may not be the best resource). it's definitely a good way to spend 4 dollars.

reviewText:
TL;DR version: This game is really good overall, but a little bit frustrating.

Long version:It's frustrating because there's so many things going on at the same time, and i find it nearly impossible to concentrate, but i guess that's because i don't have enough practice.

The graphics look good, but the aesthetic is what matters the most, and this game surely does have a good aesthetic. (It looks futuristic and Space-y, which is right, as the game is about a manta IN SPAAAAACE).

The music is retro-styled, and sounds really good.

Disclaimer:This review is based on my opinion; and due to human nature, you may or may not disagree.

EDIT:Oh, did I mention THE COLOURS!?

reviewText:
A frenetic game about shooting enemies (fishes) with your Manta. The game is pretty colorful and, well, really pretty because of it. The game can also be hard, since sometimes you have too many things blinking and flashing in the game. This is one of those game that rewards you by knowing what to do.

The music is pretty good, also, and you will like listening to it.

The game is also cheap, even more in a sale, so it is totally worth it to get it. You will probably have a good time with it.

I think the major problem of this game, though, is the absence of a system menu. But the game doesn't really need it, it would just be great to have.

reviewText:
I got this game via an Humble Bundle sale. (ergo: I like small Indie games) All other games in that bundle were tiny Indie projects with a low budget and small scope as well, but none of them was this unfinished.

I figured out what I was sipposed to do and what buttons to press by randomly pushing keyboard buttons, however there are no instrucions whatsoever. Talking about controls: I don't see any reason why I should have to fire manually, if there is no reason not to fire. It's just for the sake of holding the left mouse button. A mechanic depending on mouse positioning only (such as in soundoger+) would have sufficed.

Also a videogame has to feature an options menu. This game has the scope of a tiny mobile game, but most mobile games deliver more than this. I simply don't want to go to Windows Audio Manager to turn down the volume of an application. Not even speaking of resolution, fullscreen/windowed mode, keybindings, etc.
The music was quite nice, but even for a neon-glowing art style this game was too flashy. After every stage there are 2 popups in rapid succession that I was never able to read, because they appear and disappear far too quickly.

I have to admit, that I might have taken a deeper look into this than the obligatory 5 minutes if it was a genre that I generally enjoyed more. After all I didn't see any reason to keep playing. the game didn't even tell me the goal or controls.

TLDR: This game is unfinished. It's quite an embarrassment, considering the small scope.

reviewText:
I... I don't even know what's going on. It is not the equivalent unit weighted average method for Work in Process.

10/10 would ignore managerial accounting again.

That being said, it reminds me of Geometry Wars. It's pretty, it's fun, and it's addictive. It's not the same, though, and that's a good thing. It's quick. You die a lot. But so what? Seriously, it's a damned enjoyable game.
